I am currently seeking permission to create a new branch where we can contribute our formalized codes to Mathlib. I would also like to make PRs.

I have worked on formalizing the intrinsic interior, closure, and related properties of convex sets in a normed vector space, focusing on interactions with affine spans, closures, and intersections. I have proved several results, including that the intrinsic interior and closure of a convex set exhibit specific relationships with topological properties and affine spans.

The PR is far too long to have a hope of being reviewed in finite time. It contains at least 4 definitions, and people can quite happily debate the subtleties of a definition for a long time. All of the names in the definitions look wrong -- why affSpan? This is not part of the naming convention. The copyright header is very strange, the file seems to be copyright someone who is not in the list of authors. It's very weird to start with a definition and then immediately have a theorem which is nothing to do with the definition -- should that theorem be elsewhere? I would recommend making the first PR nearer to +100 than +800 and containing at least one definition, so a proper discussion can start. Right now people are just going to look at that PR and think "I'm not reading that, it will take me 3 hours to review it properly". Reviewing is hard work; make it easier by making a much smaller PR to start with. People will have many comments on your code.

The easiest way to "review section by section" is for the author to split up the PR into smaller PRs, because the author is the only one who knows how the PR is structured and what is an adequate and self-contained section that people could review. See the contribution guidline for more advices.

Also, if one of your smaller PRs is considered of good enough quality to be merged, it doesn't have to wait for the rest of the PRs. If you only have one big PR where one small part of it causing discussions and delays, the entire content of that PR will be held up, which is a shame.
New PR is #22371.

I just looked at this file. It defines an equivalence between the affine span of a set (an affine subspace) and its direction, choosing a point at random (using docs#choose).
Three remarks.

  1. Such an equivalence exists for any affine subspace, and if it has to enter mathlib, this is not the correct generality.
  2. Since this equivalence requires a base point, and holds for any of them, it would be better to have this point given as an argument (which the user might choose by choose).
  3. I presume that it will be used to linearize constructions on affine spaces and resort to addition of vectors. However, an API for affine spaces should be there (possibly be developed) to avoid that.
On the other hand, the properties of convex sets that are to be developed in this PR and the subsequent ones (intrinsic interior, closure, etc. ) are important.

@Joseph Myers hi~could u give some opinions?

That PR appears to be undoing a lot of Kim's recent work to split up a long file. Please don't do that. If you find yourself needing to copy or move material between files, or needing to add any imports to an existing file, the first conclusion should be that you're putting your new definitions in the wrong place and need to either find an existing file that already has the right things imported, or start a new file. You shouldn't come to a conclusion that new imports should be added to an existing file, or that material should be moved between files, without first trying to understand the design behind many of the cleanups that have been going into mathlib lately to disentangle the import graph and eliminate long files.

I think you should be adding definitions that don't mention affine subspaces, spans or anything like that at all. Specifically, Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.AffineSpace.ContinuousAffineEquiv already contains a definition ContinuousAffineEquiv.constVAdd. Try adding corresponding vaddConst (and constVSub, for completeness) definitions - analogous to those that already exist as other kinds of bundled maps, but as a ContinuousAffineEquiv in this case. Again, these should be equivalences for the whole space, not a subspace, since once you have an equivalence for the whole space, it can be used with the existing toAddTorsor when you want to apply it to a subspace.

The natural place to add those definitions is Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.AffineSpace.ContinuousAffineEquiv. You'll need to work out the right type class requirements for them. Do not add any new imports to that file. If you think extra imports are needed, create a new file instead, and carefully explain in the PR rationale exactly why each new import is needed to create those definitions.

Really thanks for your opinions. You are right!
